Paper: [Are Large Language Models Capable of Generating Human-Level Narratives?](https://aclanthology.org/2024.emnlp-main.978.pdf)
Why should we care: Analyses AI generated storylines through three discourse-level aspects: i) story arcs; ii) turning points; and iii) affective dimensions  including arousal and valence

Paper: Invited talk from our international visitor
[DeepSeek-R1: Incentivizing Reasoning Capability in LLMs via Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2501.12948)
Why should we care: DeepSeek's first-generation reasoning models DeepSeek-R1-Zero and DeepSeek-R1

Paper: [A primer on partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs)](https://besjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/epdf/10.1111/2041-210X.13692)
Why should we care: A (somewhat) gentle introduction to Partially Observed Markov Decision Processes (POMDP)
A basic introduction to one form of qualitative data analysis used widely by social science researchers

Paper: [Behavioral Homophily in Social Media via Inverse Reinforcement Learning: A Reddit Case Study](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.02943)
Why should we care: Frankie will dry-run his WWW presentation.

Paper: An overview of the thesis submission process, including Candidature assessments and selecting reviewers.

Presenter: No reading group! Find us at [WWW’25](https://www2025.thewebconf.org/)

Why should we care: Presents a reinforcement learning framework that models Covert Social Influence Operations on social media to optimise the actions of malicious agents in manipulating public opinion.

Paper: [The AI Economist: Taxation policy design via two-level deep multiagent reinforcement learning](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/sciadv.abk2607)
Why should we care: Introduces a two-level deep reinforcement learning framework where economic agents and a social planner co-adapt to design optimal taxation policies.

Paper: [Exposing Cross-Platform Coordinated Inauthentic Activity in the Run-Up to the 2024 U.S. Election](https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3696410.3714698)
Why should we care: Introduces a coordination detection model to analyse cross-platform coordinated inauthentic activity across X (formerly Twitter)  Facebook and Telegram during the 2024 U.S. Election.

Paper: [Practical Guidelines for Ideology Detection Pipelines and Psychosocial Applications](https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/ICWSM/article/download/35892/38046/39960)
Why should we care: Rohit will dry-run his ICWSM presentation
The paper investigates susceptibility to influence within social networks focusing on the differential effects of influence-driven versus spontaneous behaviors on user content adoption
An unsupervised approach translates any embedding to and from a universal latent representation

Paper: [Safety Alignment Should Be Made More Than Just a Few Tokens Deep](https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.05946)
Why should we care: Outstanding Paper Award at ICLR2025. This paper critically examines why current Large Language Models (LLMs) remain vulnerable despite extensive safety alignment training.

Paper: [A Closer Look at Machine Unlearning for Large Language Models](https://openreview.net/pdf?id=Q1MHvGmhyT)
Why should we care: Examines the training and evaluation of machine unlearning techniques on LLMs.

Paper: Invited lecture by our research visitor.
